He is seeking a loan from Kiva partner A. Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is his second loan cycle and previously he always paid on time.

His previous loan helped him improve his business by producing more tomatoes. His clients are tomato traders. When Khaled first started his work, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on this business because he learned it when he was young. In the future, he plans on improving his business further.

loans.use: To purchase tools.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph T. is married and the father of two young children. He is 31 years old and provides transportation services on his motorbike. For the last 5 years, Joseph has driven passengers on his motorbike along with one employee with whom he initially switched shifts; later the employee drove a second rented bike.

With the loan, Joseph plans to purchase a second motor bike so that he can stop renting one. He hopes, with increased income, he will be able to complete the extension of his apartment where he lives with his family. Joseph is a first time borrower at ARD and the sole breadwinner for his family.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Sary

texts.en:
Mrs. Sary H., 54 (shown in the picture with her husband), and her husband, Mr. Yet Prum, 61, have been married since 1975 and have six children - four sons and two daughters. One of them is married and lives outside the family home, one son is a construction worker, one daughter works in a garment factory and another son is a driver. They are living in a small village off of National Road number Two about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sary and her husband are farmers. To earn extra income to support the family, Sary started a new business selling meal in her village. She is applying for a loan of US $300 to use for this new business.

loans.use: To use for her new business selling meal.

loans.name: Muoka

texts.en:
A father of ten and a great grandfather to four, Muoka is a 70 year old, successful water vendor in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. He has been in this business for 18 years and hopes to be a main water supplier to construction sites in the area. He is requesting a loan of Kes. 10,000 to buy an additional cart for transporting water. He aspires to buy a lorry in ten years for water supply. He describes himself as determined.

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy an additional cart to transport water.

loans.name: Zaynab

texts.en:
Zaynab is a 31 year-old woman who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with her husband. For two years, Zaynab has been selling clothes. She also sells women’s accessories and toys for children. She is seeking a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop including the collection for the new season. This is her second loan cycle and previously she paid on time.

Her previous loan helped improve her sales by diversifying her merchandise. Her clients are people from her region. When Zaynab first started her work, she didn’t face difficulties except finding the proper place to open her shop. She decided on her business because she likes what she does and from a young age she wanted to open a clothing shop. In the future, she plans on improving her business further.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John K. is 38 years old. He is a single parent and has one daughter who is in primary school. He is a college graduate, who worked briefly as Admin Officer with a mobile company, and resigned to go into private business. He has 14 months of experience in business and sells soft drinks and liquor wholesale from a shop which he rents at New London Transit Lorry Park, Bo.

John is seeking a loan of Le 4,000,000 for 8 months to buy more drinks and fill the empty space in his store so that he will be able to meet the market demand of his customers.

John is a firm believer in the values of private enterprise. Among his many hopes and ambitions, John plans to use the proceeds from his store to support his daughter in school and to eventually own land on which to build a home. In the near future, John hopes to serve as an agent for his suppliers.

loans.use: To buy more beverages for his store

loans.name: Ziad

texts.en:
Ziad is a 29 year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and child. Ziad has been working as a mechanic for nine years. He installs spare parts and changes car oil. He is seeking a loan from Kiva partner A. Majmoua in order to purchase additionA. tools for his business. This is the first time that he has requested a loan.

Ziad's clients are his friends and neighbors. When Ziad first started his work, he had some financiA. issues. He decided on this business because of his experience in car mechanics. In the future, he plans on improving his business further.

loans.use: To purchase tools.

loans.name: Kadie

texts.en:
Kadie is a trader who sells textiles (cotton wax prints and lace materials). She is married to a building contractor and has five dependents, two of whom are her kids. One of her children is in secondary school and the other in primary school. She has ten years of business experience.

Kadie is seeking a Le 3,000,000 loan for six months in order to buy additional cloth from Guinea as well as beverages and toiletries which she supplies to NGOs in Bo. Her shop is rented and is located in the heart of the central market—Shenge. She is dedicated to her business and works very hard. Kadie usually works alone unless she needs additional help during the holidays at which time she recruits the help of her children.

Kadie hopes that her income will enable her to continue to pay her kids' school fees as well as help to finish their home which is under construction.

loans.use: To buy textiles for her store

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
A grandmother to eight and a mother of ten, Anna is a 65 year old businesswoman who manufactures and sells sisal ropes wholesale. She sells her products to retail shops that deal with ropes and has been in this business for 18 years. She is requesting for a loan of Kes. 15,000 to add stock of raw sisal. She hopes to be the main supplier of ropes in the region, and to raise enough money out of her business profits to build her family a home and a premise on which to run her business. She describes herself as hardworking.

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy raw sisal.

loans.name: Haja Isatu

texts.en:
Haja Isatu D. is a single parent of two daughters--one in university and the other in high school. In addition to her children, Haja supports her two sisters. Her children and her sisters are all actively involved in her business. They are not salaried employees but earn a nominal wage on days when they volunteer to help out at the store. She enjoys a substantial amount of family support in her business and is happy to have it.

Haja, who is 46 years old, has over 14 years of business experience, and currently sells cosmetics, fashion accessories, and toiletries. She travels to purchase from suppliers located in Guinea.

Haja rents her shop which is located along a row of business enterprises at Mahei Boima Road. With this loan, she plans to expanded her core product offerings in order to attract additional customers. She is a repeat borrower of ARD.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and fashion accessories for her store

loans.name: Jawad

texts.en:
Jawad is a 22-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon. He owns a barber shop and also sells beauty products. He requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is the first time that Jawad has requested a loan.

When Jawad first started his work, he didn’t face difficulties; his clients are his friends and neighbors. He decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
God Is Able is a group of five borrowers led by Matinah D. who is 29 years old. She is a single mother of three children aged 1 to 9 years old and their educational levels  kindergarten-2nd grade. Matinah also cares for two siblings.

Matinah is a 12th grade student but also does business to support she and her children in order to continue education. She and her family lives in Banjour but she works in the Dualla market, a big market where farmers brings their goods from out of town to sell. It is situated north of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia.

Matinah's business is selling chicken and spare-ribs in the Dualla market. She has been running this business for five years and gives appreciation to the business for taking care of she and her family; providing a more comfortable life for them.

Because Matinah keeps her business place clean and neat, customers are attracted by that. She needs this loan in order to purchase more new goods to serve her customers.

Matinah is hoping to become an importer of different kinds of goods. She dreams of building a house for herself and her family.

loans.use: to purchase more new goods to serve her customers.

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en:
Abdul is married to a nurse who works with a local hospital. He has 4 children all under 18 years of age. He is 36 years old and has been in the shoe-selling business for over 15 years. Abdul plans to use the loan to purchase more inventory. With the income generated at his store, Abdul hopes to complete the on-going construction of his house which still needs a roof, windows, and doors.

Abdul has successfully borrowed from ARD over 5 times as a participant in group loans. This is Abdul’s first individual loan.

loans.use: To buy shoes

loans.name: Nabil

texts.en:
Nabil is a 35 year old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Nabil has owned a barber shop for the last twelve years.. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools and a new seat for his work. This is his fourth cycle and he has always paid on time. 
His previous loans helped him improve his work and change the décor of his shop to make it more attractive. When Nabil first started his work, he had some financial issues; his clients are his friends and neighbors. He decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on improving his work

loans.use: To purchase tools and a new seat for his work.

loans.name: Jamal

texts.en:
JamA. is a 28-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children.

JamA. has been working as a car repairer and painter for a few years now. He requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase tools, a compressor and paint for his work. This is his fourth loan and he has always repaid on time.

JamA.’s previous loans helped him improve and adapt himself with the required tools for his work. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his work, he had some financiA. issues. He decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools, a compressor and paint

loans.name: Isaack

texts.en:
Isaak is a 37 year old married father of six children, with four in school. He is a bus agent at the Kyumbi stage (station) in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. He makes bookings for passengers going to Mombasa. He has been in his business for seven years and was previously a farmer. He earns extra income running retail shops in Kyumbi and Muumandu towns. 

He is requesting a loan for Kes. 40,000 to add stock of maize and beans to his retail shops. In the future he hopes to buy a truck to transport dry maize, beans, and onions throughout the surrounding districts and also own a chain of wholesale shops so that he may improve the living standards of his family. He describes himself as hardworking, positive about life, and hopeful.

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add stock of maize and beans to his shops.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Louer un atelier et acheter d’autres machines à coudre

loans.name: Melsie

texts.en:
Melsie A. M. is a married woman with three dependents. Melise leases a shop at Tobu Market and runs a general store that sells foodstuffs, toiletries, and other sundry products. She has been in business for two years and has requested a loan to purchase additional provisions and local food for her store.

Melsie intends to use proceeds from the loan to pay school fees for her kids and build her own food store in the future. She has a shop assistant who normally helps her in her business while she uses part of her day to work as a cashier at a non-profit organization.

Melsie hopes to eventually buy land and build a house from income generated from her business.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs for her store

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is a 31 year old mother of two who runs a grocery store in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. She has been in this business for five years and hopes to open multiple outlets in the region. She is requesting a loan of Kes. 20,000 to buy sacks of potatoes, cabbage, tomatoes, and onions. She hopes to improve her living standards and earn more to provide a better life for her family. 

She describes herself as hardworking and determined to educate her two children and mentor them into successful life.

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items to sell in her store.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is a 40-year-old business lady who runs a grocery in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. She has been running this business for the last five years. She is requesting a loan of 15,000 shillings to add potatoes, tomatoes, cabbages, kale and butternut to her stock. She hopes to become a supplier of groceries to schools and hospitals and to create employment. She describes herself as very hardworking.

About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a deposit-taking micro-finance company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her shop

loans.name: Saahkem

texts.en:
(
Born in 1954, D. is married with seven children; she lives in Musang, within the urban town of Bamenda, Cameroon.  With this loan, D. plans to invest in Roasting of fish and frying of gateaux.  She plans to buy fresh fish, charcoal and spices for the roasting of fish. She will also buy flour, yeast, firewood, Sugar, groundnut oil, frying pan and spoon which will enable her to fry her gateaux. 
This is D. seven  loan; she has been a member of GHAPE since 1999.She has a great deal of experience in her business; added to that, she will be selling in schools during lunch break.  Over the years, her customers have been increasing on regular basis. She also has an excellent site for her business which is located near the road and is accessible to many people.

She plans to use the profit from her business to build a house and pay her children school fees. She will also reinvest part in the business. The rest will be used to clothe her children, provide medical assistance to her family, and feed her family.  

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of fresh fish, spices, flour, sugar, groundnut oil, yeast, firewood, frying pan and spoon and paying of rents.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: building a shed and buying machinery

loans.name: Felistus

texts.en:
Felistus is a 38-year-old married mother of four who sells new and used clothes in Machakos, a busy market town near Nairobi. She has been in this business for five years and previously worked in farming. She is requesting a loan for 40,000 shillings to buy more clothes to sell. She describes herself as hardworking and optimistic. Her dream is to own a big well stocked shop so that she can earn enough to pay university fees for all four of her children.

texts.en:
Fotibu is married to Naah and blessed with five children. He lives in Ntasen, Bamenda, Cameroon. He is a very hardworking man. He has faced numerous difficulties especially thieves who robbed him, land cases in court, death of her brother and sister and also his accident he had on a motor bike last year. N. joined GHAPE since 2005 and now he is requesting for his fourth loan from GHAPE.
 He plans to invest this loan in the purchase of feed, zinc, plank and nails. He intends to contribute from his saving the sum of 100000 FRS towards the realization of this business project. The profit which he will have from the loan will be used to educate his children improve on her living style and pay hospital bills.

GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is a widow with two children. She lives in a quarter far off the town of Bamenda, Cameroon. She plans to invest this loan in a township taxi. In particular, she will purchase an engine for the car, since she has already bought other parts of the taxi and the only part remaining to be purchased is the motor engine. With this taxi, she will help her community to transport their farm produce to the market. She will also help to transport her neighbours to their various farms. Accessibility to the farm and market will no longer be any problem in her locality.

This is Anna’s tenth loan; she has been a GHAPE member since 1998. With the profit from this loan, Anna plans to construct a house. She also plans to take care of her family, ensuring that they eat well and buy their medications. Above all, she will help to educate her grandchildren to higher levels. She knows she will be able to repay this loan because of the low interest rate and the small repayment instalments.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.name: With God All Is Thing Are Possible Group

texts.en:
With God All Is Thing are Possible is a group of 5 borrowers led by Elizabeth T..  Elizabeth is 41 years old and a single mother of a 24-year-old.  Her child has a 12th-grade education. 
 
Elizabeth is a high-school graduate but could not continue to university due to poverty. She and her family live in Banjour,  but she works in the Dualla market, north of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. 

Elizabeth is a retailer of general goods such as soap, dry goods, charcoal, etc. in the Dualla market, a large market where farmers bring goods from out of town to sell. She has been running this business for 10 years and appreciates that the business has supported her family.  

Elizabeth takes pride in giving her customers affordable prices and good service. She hopes to build a big shop in the Dualla Market in the future. She is seeking a loan to purchase more goods to improve her business.  She dreams of building a house for herself and her family.

This is Alian's seventh loan; she has been a GHAPE member since 1998. She is a long time mixed farmer and produces all species of tubers.

With the profit from this loan, Alian plans to take care of her family, ensure that they eat well and buy their medication.  She knows she will be able to repay this loan because of the low interest rate and the small repayment installments.

Her husband is an artist. Florence has been selling fabrics, children’s sandals, dresses and ladies wear since 2004. She supports the husband in the payment of bills and school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more fabrics, sandals and ladies wear for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest into her business.

texts.fr: Bineta N. est une commerçante de prêt-à-porter pour homme et femme, chaussures et sacs de ville, âgée de 39 ans, elle est mariée. Dans le cadre de l’agrandissement de ses locaux Mme N. demande ce prêt afin d’augmenter sa production et sa clientèle ce qui lui permettra d’obtenir plus de revenus pour payer les frais de scolarité de sa fille qui est dans un collège privé
texts.en:
Bineta N. sells ready-to-wear for men and women, shoes, and handbags. She is 39 and married. In the intention of expanding her sales point, Mrs. N. is requesting this loan to grow her business and her clientele, which will allow her to earn more money to use for the school fees of her daughter who attends a private school.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolstering her little business

loans.name: Abduhalim

texts.en:
Abduhalim is married with a three children. He had to find a way to support his family and that is how he ended up as a taxi driver. He owns a car and provides transportation services throughout Khujand, Tajikistan. The business is the only source of income for his family. Abduhalim works very hard, sometimes without days off or vacation, in order to bring in enough income. Abduhalim has been in this business for 3 years. His determination and strong will to succeed have helped him keep his business stable and sustainable and have promoted its expansion. Abduhalim would like to get a loan for $2600 USD in order to replace his car with the new one. With that way he will improve his business and earn more money by attracting more clients. We are confident that the modesty, diligence and responsibility that have helped Abduhalim develop his venture and gain a good reputation among other taxi drivers will help him promptly repay this loan and allow him to succeed in his business endeavors. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Nelly De

texts.es: Nelly tiene a todos sus hijos que son mayores de edad y también son independientes. Nelly actualmente vive en la casa de sus hijas, Nelly trabaja como operaria de costura en una sastrería conocida de la zona cerca de donde vive. Por otra parte también desarrolla en su domicilio todo tipo de confecciones y arreglos de vestimenta, claro esto ya de manera particular e independiente. La competnecia en este rubro es mediana, lo que le favorece es el hecho de trabajar en una sastrería que tiene ya una experiencia y reputación ganada. El crédito está destinado a la reparación de su máquina de costurar y a la cancelación de un saldo anterior que adeuda. Esta será la cuarta operación de crédito con la institución y durante el tiempo de la relación comercial ella demostró responsabilidad en el pago de sus cuotas.
texts.en:
All of Nelly’s children are older and on their own. Nelly currently lives in her daughters’ home. She works as a seamstress in a tailors that is well known in her area. She also takes in sewing at home as an independent contractor and makes all sorts of different clothes and repairs. There is some competition in this field, but not much. What helps her is that she also works at a well regarded and established tailor. The loan is to fix her sewing machine and to pay off the balance on an earlier debt. This will be her fourth loan with this institution; she has proved herself responsible in paying her installments.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fix a sewing machine and pay off balance on earlier debt

loans.name: Yolanda De

texts.es: Yolanda tiene 48 años de edad, en su carnet de identidad figura como casada, pero actualmente está separada de su esposo desde hace mucho tiempo atrás. Tiene 3 hijos, de los cuales solamente uno depende  de ella. La vivienda con la que cuenta es propia. Yolanda es propietaria de una carpintería, donde elabora una variedad de productos tales como puertas, ventanas, catres, roperos y otros. Cuenta con dos ayudantes, uno de ellos está a tiempo completo y el otro a medio tiempo. Se dedica a esta actividad desde hace diez años. En la zona donde está ubicado su negocio no existen otras carpinterías, por lo tanto el nivel de competencia en la zona es relativamente bajo, pero a nivel de departamento existen muchas personas que se dedican a esta actividad. El destino del crédito es para compra de equipo para la carpintería, una máquina cepilladora y para compra de madera. Es el tercer crédito al que accede Yolanda. Presento un  buen comportamiento en los dos anteriores créditos. No presenta antecedentes negativos el sistema financiero.

Since being married, Americo dedicates his time to working with his truck to take merchandise and sell in various nearby cities. He counts on forming clients in order to have a secure job, so that he will have the possibility of giving his children a good education so they have a good profession. 
He wants a loan to buy shorts, pants, jeans, capris, undergarments, and other articles to sell and offer his clients.

loans.name: Mariya

texts.en:
Mariya is married with two grown children: a 30-year-old daughter and a 25-year-old son. She is an entrepreneur from Ivano-Frankivsk. She runs a retail business selling women’s and children’s clothing and footwear. Mariya owned four retail kiosks in the same market called Central Industrial Market. However, a recent fire in a storage where she used to keep all he inventory destroyed most of her merchandise and caused much damage to her business. As a result of fire damage, Mariya currently owns only two kiosks. One of the main attractions of her business is affordable prices. Mariya has been in this business for 12 years. Presently, her monthly income is about 6,000 Grivnyas. 

Mariya is requesting a 12,000 Grivnya loan to purchase 20 women’s suits, 30 blouses and 40 sweat suits. She is hoping to generate additional income and make some savings for upcoming winter when market sales usually go down. One of Mariya’s long-term plans is to open a second vending location.

texts.fr:
Les six  membres du groupe Confiance sont des femmes mariées  ayant en moyenne 40 ans et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à Sanoubougou  I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur  premier prêt et espèrent maintenir cette relation. 
Elles font la vente du bois de chauffe, d’huile alimentaire, de cartes de crédits téléphoniques prépayées, des tissus et  des chaussures.
 Avec ce premier  prêt, elles comptent acheter, 1chargement de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 4 bidons de 20 litres d’huile alimentaire, 10cartes de crédits de 2000FCFA, 30 cartes de crédits de 1000FCFA, 5 rouleaux de tissus pour homme et  3 douzaines de chaussures. Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et les villages avoisinants et effectuent leurs ventes dans les différents marchés tel celui de Sanoubougou, dans les  quartiers de la ville de Sikasso et à domicile, au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, mais  souvent à crédit.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille; l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
Elles espèrent sur des prêts plus élevés pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  pouvoir aménager un point de vente.
texts.en:
The six members of the 'Confiance' group are married women with an average age of 40 and on average, 4 children. They mostly live in monogamous families in Sanoubougou I, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

They work with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the needs of their clientele; they are on their first loan and are hoping to maintain this relationship.

They sell firewood, cooking oil, prepaid telephone cards, fabrics, and shoes. With this first loan they hope to buy 1 truckload of firewood, 4 jerrycans of 20 liters of cooking oil, 10 phone cards at 2000 F CFA, 30 cards at 1000 F CFA, 5 bolts of cloth for men, and 3 dozen shoes. They do their buying in the marketplace of Sikasso and the surrounding villages and make their sales in the various markets such as the one at Sanoubougou, in the neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso, and out of their homes, for cash, to a clientele composed of men and women, and often for credit.

They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 22,500 F CFA of which part will be saved or used for family expenses with the remainder invested back into their businesses. They are looking forward to receiving higher amounts in future so that they can satisfy their clientele appropriately and be able to open up a sales point.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Carlos Z. is 21 years old, single, and lives with his grandfather. He started working as a carpenter when he was very young, approximately in 2000. He grandfather gave him money for his own carpentry business. He works for orders in two places in the city, and he has people who work for him. 
He wants to invest his credit in buying more wood, to complete the jobs he already has lined up. His dream is to have a carpenter shop in the center of the city, so that he can work very hard.

loans.use: To purchase wood and other materials

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en:
Tamara is a widow. She lives and runs her venture in Pavlograd. She sells women’s outer clothing items. Tamara owns a vending kiosk in the central marketplace of her hometown. She launched this enterprise 12 years ago. Currently, she has about 30,000 Grivnyas in turnover capital. Her net profit is about 5,500-8,000 Grivnyas a month.

Tamara is seeking a loan of 9,400 Grivnyas to increase her working capital. She is hoping to buy durable and high quality inventory, which will definitely sell well this fall/winter season. Tamara lives with her daughter and a grandson. She always says their welfare is the main goal of her life. Therefore, she is willing to work hard to make sure her family has everything it needs. 
Note: In the picture, Tamara is in red shirt.

loans.use: To increase working capital to buy more inventory

loans.name: Soro Yiriwa Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Soro Yiriwa (5 femmes mariées  et  1 célibataire) ont  en moyenne 38ans et en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à Sanoubougou  I un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative de la république  du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur cinquième  prêt solidaire après avoir correctement remboursés tous prêts précédents.
 Elles font la vente de chenilles de karité, d’atièkè, de poisson, de condiments, des savons, des  tissus et  des produits de beauté. 
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter,  2 sacs de 100kg de chenilles de karité, 2 sacs d’atièkè, 5 kg de poissons frais, 5 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 2 cartons de savons(BF), 2 rouleaux de tissus pour homme et 6 emballages de produits de beauté. Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et les villages avoisinants et vendent au marché de Sanoubougou I, dans les autres quartiers de la ville de Sikasso et à domicile. Elles vendent au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
  Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23.250 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille; l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles comptent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  pouvoir aménager un point de vente.
texts.en:
The six members of Soro Yiriwa Group (five married women and one single woman), on average, are 38 years old and have three children. Most of them live in monogamous families in Sanoubougou I, a neighborhood of the city of Sikasso in the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They have joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the demand of their customers. This is their fifth group loan and they have repaid all their previous loans on schedule.

Their businesses consist in selling karité (shea nuts), atièkè (a dish made of seasoned manioc sold with fish), fish, condiments, soap, cloths and beauty products. They will use their new loan to buy 2 sacks of 100 kg karité, 2 sacks of atièkè, 5 kg fresh fish, 5 boxes of food condiments, 2 boxes of BF soap, 2 rolls of cloth for men and 6 packages of beauty products. They buy their products in the city of Sikasso and the nearby villages, and they sell them at the market in Sanoubougou I, in the other neighborhoods of Sikasso and at home. They sell for cash and often on credit to a clientele made up of men and women.

They expect to make an average profit of 23,250 CFA francs (US$52) each per month. They will save or spend part of their profit to provide for their families and reinvest part of it in their businesses. They expect to have more capital at their disposal to better meet the demand of their customers and to be able to set up a sales outlet.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products

loans.name: Elida

texts.en:
Elida A. is 20 years old, single, and lives with her parents.
Elida started works as a door-to-door salesperson, at the beginning of 2000. With a small amount of capital, she sold spices around the city, and has a business in the market. She also has her markets around the city that has different clients in different places. 
She invested credit in buying more merchandise to sell (such as clothes, tennis shoes, sandals, and other vairious things).

loans.use: Clothing, Shoes, Foodstuffs

loans.name: Abdoulaye

texts.fr:
Monsieur Abdoulaye D. est un homme marié, né le 21 Août 1971à Kadiolo (préfecture de Sikasso), père de 4 enfants, il vit dans un foyer   monogame avec son épouse et leurs enfants à Kaï, relevant de la commune rurale de Loulouni.(troisième région du Mali)
Abdoulaye D. est soudeur à Kaï depuis plusieurs années, en plus de ce métier, il fait le commerce de céréales  il ya 3 ans. Expérimenté en raison des années d’exercices dans le commerce, il mène les deux activités  avec harmonie. 
Il est à sa deuxième  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.
Il compte acheter avec son prêt, 1 tonne et 1/2  de maïs et 1 tonne et 1/2  de mil. 
Il s’approvisionne à Kaï (sa localité de résidence) et environnants mais surtout dans le marché de Loulouni les jours de foires. Il vend sur commande,  en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Il envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50.000FCFA qui sera utilisé en grande partie pour augmenter le fonds de commerce. 
Il ambitionne  construire un grand magasin de stockage de céréales et devenir un grossiste.

loans.use: Achat de céréales.

loans.name: Taisya

texts.en:
Taisya is a widow. She is retired, however, she chooses to have an active and busy life. Taisya runs a small business selling groceries. She owns a small kiosk on the property of a local polyclinic in her home town of Kamenka. She has two grown daughters who sometimes help her in the market. Taisya has been in this business for 12 years. Currently, she has about 30,000 Grivnyas of goods in inventory. Her monthly net profit amounts to 6,000-7,000 Grivnyas.

Taisya is requesting a loan of 10,318 Grivnyas to increase merchandise and purchase several extra types of confectionery. Taisya believes fresh grocery items and cookies are always in demand, especially at the polyclinic, where there are no other stores or food kiosks. Taisya has promptly repaid 7 previous loans.

loans.use: To increase assorted merchandise for sale

loans.name: Elvio

texts.en: Elvio Barrios is a storekeeper and dedicates himself to selling direct billing merchandise. He started in the area with his father and and earned enough savings to open his own business. Elvio’s dream is to open a commercial shop where he can exhibit his merchandise to sell. He will use this loan to buy merchandise such as electronics, power saws and other things. Elvio is 28 years old, single and lives with his brothers and mother.

loans.use: To buy electronics and tools

loans.name: Aguibou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Aguibou C. est marié à une femme et père de 6 enfants. Il est né le 22 Janvier 1967 à Oueleni –Fiebala dans la commune rurale de Loulouni préfecture de Kadiolo, 3eme région administrative du Mali.  Il vit  dans un foyer monogame  dans son village natal relevant  de Loulouni.
Il est gérant de la pharmacie du Centre de Santé Communautaire (C.S.Com.) de Oueleni-fiebala depuis plusieurs années et fait également le commerce de céréales il y a une année. Il mène les  deux activités sans difficulté. 
Il est à sa deuxième  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, le prêt  passé s’est bien dénoué. 
Il compte acheter avec son prêt, 1 tonne de maïs et de mil. Il s’approvisionne à Kaï et environnants mais aussi au marché de Loulouni les jours de foire. Il vend  sur commande, en détail, au comptant ou à crédit; à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Il envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 45.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisé pour augmenter son fonds de commerce et l’autre partie mise en épargne. 
Il ambitionne dans l’avenir construire une maison à usage d’habitation à Sikasso.

loans.use: Achat de céréales.

loans.name: Alasseni

texts.fr:
Monsieur Alasseni Sanogo est marié à deux  femmes et  père de 4 enfants. Il est né le 17 Juin 1974 à Kaï  dans la commune rurale de Loulouni, préfecture de Kadiolo, 3eme région administrative  de la république du Mali.  Il vit  avec ses  épouses et leurs enfants à Kaï.
Il est cultivateur depuis son jeune âge et a appris à faire le commerce depuis 5 ans. Expérimenté en raison des années d’exercices dans le commerce de céréales, il le mène aujourd’hui avec réussite. 
Il est à sa deuxième  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Le prêt  passé s’est bien déroulé et il compte maintenir cette collaboration pour satisfaire ses nombreux clients dont les demandes ne cessent d’augmenter.  
Il compte acheter avec son prêt, 2 tonnes de maïs et de mil. Elle s’approvisionne à Kaï et environnants mais aussi au marché de Loulouni le jour de foire.  Il vend  en gros et en détail, au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
 Il envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 80.000FCFA qui sera utilisé en grande partie pour augmenter le fonds de commerce. 
Il ambitionne être un grossiste et  avoir un camion de transport.
texts.en:
Mr Alasseni S. is married with two wives and the father of four children. He was born on June 17, 1974 in Kaï, located in the rural town of Loulouni, prefecture of Kadiolo, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. He lives with his wives and their children in Kaï. He has been a farmer since a very young age and has learnt the trade business for five years. After all these years of experience he is now a successful trader of cereals.

This is his second loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. He has repaid his previous loan on schedule and wants to continue his cooperation with us to meet the ever rising demand of his customers.

Alasseni will use his loan to buy 2 tons of corn and millet. He gets his supplies in Kaï and in the nearby villages, but also at the market in Loulouni. He sells retail or in bulk, cash or credit, to a clientele made up of men and women. He expects to make a monthly profit of 80,000 CFA francs (US$180) which he will mostly reinvest in his business. His ambition is to become a wholesaler and own a truck for transportation.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Yacouba

texts.fr:
Monsieur Yacouba S. est marié à une  femme, père de 6 enfants, il est né le 31 Décembre 1974 à Kaï dans la commune rurale de  Loulouni, préfecture de Kadiolo, 3eme région administrative de la république du Mali.  Il vit avec son épouse et ses  enfants à Kaï dans un foyer monogame.
Il est commerçant  d’articles divers de boutique depuis plusieurs années  et fait  en plus, le commerce de céréales depuis 11 ans. Expérimenté en raison des années dans le commerce, Il les mène avec réussite.
Il est à sa deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Le prêt passé a été bien remboursé et il souhaite continuer avec l’institution pour pouvoir satisfaire ses clients. 
Il compte acheter avec son prêt, 5 paquets d’articles divers de boutiques(des fournitures d’écoliers) et 1 tonne de céréales (riz et haricot). Il s’approvisionne à Sikasso ville et au marché de Loulouni les jours de foire. Il vend au comptant ou à crédit, en gros et en détail, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Il envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour augmenter le fonds de commerce et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne car il ambitionne  construire une maison à usage d’habitation à Sikasso.

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers de boutique et de céréales.

loans.name: Alla Kan Soutra Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  membres du groupe Alla kan soutra sont des femmes mariées  avec en moyenne  32ans et en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames au  Millionkin un des quartiers de la ville de Loulouni, 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle qui ne cesse de croître. 
Elles  vendent des fruits, des condiments alimentaires, du haricot et font de la restauration.
Avec leur prêt, elles comptent acheter, des fruits (2 régime de bananes 3paniers d’oranges), 5 paquets de condiments alimentaires, 50kg de graine de haricot, 50kg de riz et 3 paquets condiments pour la restauration.  Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Loulouni ville le jour de foire et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent à Loulouni ville, à domicile, au marché et dans les différents quartiers de façon ambulante, au comptant  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 11.000FCFA ont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille; l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
Elles comptent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  pouvoir aménager un endroit  pour leur  vente.
texts.en:
The four members of Alla Kan Soutra Group are married women who, on average, are 32 years old and have three children. Most of them live in monogamous families in Millionkin, a neighborhood of the city of Loulouni in the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They have just joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the ever rising demand of their customers.

They sell fruits, food condiments and beans, and are active in catering. They will use their loan to buy fruits (2 bunches of bananas and 3 baskets of oranges), 5 boxes of food condiments, 50 kg of dried beans, 50 kg of rice and 3 boxes of condiments for the catering business. They get their supplies at the market of the city of Loulouni and in the nearby villages. They sell their products in Loulouni, either at home and at the market, or by hawking in the various neighborhoods. They sell for cash and often on credit to a clientele made up of men and women.

They expect to make an average profit of 11,000 CFA francs (US$25) each per month. They will save or spend part of their profit to provide for their families and reinvest part of it in their businesses. They expect to have more capital at their disposal to better meet the demand of their customers and to be able to set up a sales outlet.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products

loans.name: Benkadi. Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Benkadi sont des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et 2 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à Kokouna un des villages de la commune rurale  de Loulouni, 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt. Le précédent a été bien remboursé. 
Elles font la vente de poissons fumés, de cous- cous et de condiments alimentaires.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 1panier et ½ de poissons fumés,  200kg de sorgho, 25kg de sucre et 6 paquets de condiments alimentaires.  Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Loulouni ville et les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent aux marchés de Loulouni, Dallen et à domicile, au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille; l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles comptent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  pouvoir aménager un endroit pour leur vente.

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers.

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario G. is 54 years old and has been married for 25 years to Guillermina Jiménez, who is 49 years old. They have three children. Two of them have grown up and left the house but still help their parents economically. The third child is a daughter who is 14 years old and lives with them. She is in 7th grade.

Mario started his business nine years ago. He prepares seasonings in a commercialized place in different businesses and has clients in the same place as his merchandise. With his loan he wants to buy quality seasonings to secure a better life and augment his profits.

loans.use: To buy seasoning and spices

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro is 23 years old, single, and lives with his parents. He has a small carpentry business with his father. They make all kinds of furniture, including wardrobes, mesh cupboards to store dry meat, and shelves. Pedro has obtained a good amount of clients. In 2006, he had a large workload from the carpentry business, but his father was sick and Pedro could not work.

Pedro's dream is to make his carpentry business bigger and to have a shop to exhibit his furniture. He is using his loan to buy a motor to use in his business.

loans.use: To buy a motor for his carpentry business

loans.name: Fotemogoban. Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Fotemogoban sont  des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 37 et 2 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à Kokouna un des villages de la commune rurale de Loulouni, 3ème région administrative de la république  du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt. solidaire. Le premier s’est bien dénoué. 
Elles font la vente de  beurre de karité, de condiments alimentaires et de céréales.
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 150kg de beurre de karité, 6 paquets de condiments alimentaires et 3sacs de 100kg céréales (maïs et sorgho).  Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Loulouni ville et les villages avoisinants et effectuent leur ventes aux marchés de Loulouni, Dallen et à domicile, au comptant, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille; l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles comptent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  pouvoir aménager un point de vente.
texts.en:
The four members of the Fotemogoban group are married women who on average are 37 years old, with two children. They are, for the most part in monogamous families living in Kokouna, one of the villages in the rural district of Loulouni, the third administrative region in the Republic of Mali. They work with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance company to meet their customers needs and are about to make their second loan. Their first loan has been repaid in full. They sell karite butter ( a cosmetic cream), basic food condiments and cereals With their new loan, they plan to buy 150 kg of karite butter, 6 boxes of basic food condiments and 3 x 100 kg sacs of cereal grains (corn and sorgho). They buy provisions at the market place in Loulouni and in neighboring villages and sell their products at the markets in Loulouni and Dallen and from their homes. They sell their products for cash to a clientele of both women and men. They each hope to earn a monthly profit of 22,500 Francs CFA. A part will be used for savings and family needs and a part to be invested in their businesses. They would like to increase their operating capital to increase their customers satisfaction and better manage their sales.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase products for resale

loans.name: Sabougnouma. Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont des femmes mariées  avec en moyenne  28ans et 2 enfants. Elles  vivent  dans des familles monogames au Millionkin un des quartiers de la ville de Loulouni, 3ème région administrative de la république  du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle qui ne cesse de croître. 
Elles  font de la restauration avec la préparation et la vente d’atiéké et de haricot cuisinés.
Avec leur premier prêt, elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité d’atièkè, de l’huile et du haricot (50kg de graine de haricot).  Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Loulouni ville et les villages avoisinants et  vendent à Loulouni ville,  à domicile, au marché et dans les quartiers de façon ambulante. Elles vendent au comptant  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille; l’autre partie sera réinvestie dans les activités.
Elles comptent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  pouvoir aménager un point de vente.

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers pour la restauration.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes B. sells gari and charcoal at Elmina near Emina. Agnes has no educational background. She is married and has four children. She contributes to the payment of school fees and settlement of bills.

Agnes has been in the business of selling gari and charcoal since 1989. Her loan will be used to buy maize, gari and charcoal for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and reinvest into her business.

loans.use: To buy maize, gari and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is thirty–five years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, who are both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town.

Lydia is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew. She buys bags of rice from nearby towns. Lydia has been in business for nine years and wants a loan to buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is forty – three years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town. Joyce is a food vendor. She runs a chop bar. She prepares and sells all kinds of local dishes. Joyce buys her raw materials from nearby towns. She has been in business for over twenty – two years and wants a loan to buy food stuffs and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy food stuffs

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida is thirty–two years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town.

Vida is a food vendor. She prepares and sells kenkey with pepper and fried fish. She buys bags of maize from nearby towns. Vida has been in business for two years and wants a loan to buy bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna is fifty–five years old. She is married and has four children who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Dormaa of the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town. Anna is a trader, who trades in plantain. She buys from nearby towns and supplies food vendors and retailers in her community. Anna also treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. She has been in business for over fifteen years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy plantain

loans.name: God Bless You Group

texts.en:
God IS Able is a group of 5 borrowers led by Anthony R.. He is 41 years old, married and has 3 children.
Anthony and his family live in Brewer Ville, Liberia.  

Anthony sells fish. He buys fish from fishermen and sells it to the residents of Brewer Ville. He has been running this business for 7 years and hopes to establish a shop for his business. He needs this loan in order to increase capital to improve and expand his business. In addition to improving his business, Anthony dreams of building a house for his family.

loans.use: He need this loan in order to increase capital to improve business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is thirty – nine years old. She is single and has no child. She lives in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town. Agnes is a trader. She trades in foot wears. She buys all kinds of foot wears from Kumasi. She hawks to sell in her community and also treks to nearby communities to sell. Agnes has been in business for over eighteen years. She wants a loan to buy goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy foot wears

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is a 45 year old married woman with two healthy and wonderful children. One is currently in school while the other has just completed his senior year in high school and is waiting for his results. She is a determined worker and her hard work contributes greatly to the family. She sells ingredients like spices, rice, vegetables, oil, etc. She arranges them in a bowl and sells the ingredients through hawking in the markets around the community where she lives. She has been in this business for the last four years to take care of her children and support her husband. Because of her work, she is able to pay for them to go to school and be healthy. The demand for her food ingredients is high but she does not have enough money to meet the demand. She would like a loan to buy rice, spices, and vegetables etc. She takes delivery of goods from Kumasi in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy ingredients like spices, meat, vegetables, and bags of rice, etc.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is sixty two years old, divorced, and the mother of seven children. Three of her children are currently in school while the other four older children work. To support them, Grace has been trading food for six years now. She always tries to maximize profit through Just In Time delivery (JIT). She trades wheat and spices such as maize and pepper in bulk. She buys these crops directly from farmers at a relatively low price. She sells them at the local market in the town where she lives with her family. She also brings some of her goods to nearby markets to sell. She says she wants to use the loan to buy the goods in bulk so that she can distribute to a greater number of customers. She believes this will prevent her from frequent traveling and increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy more food like maize and pepper in bulk.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca is 31 years old.  She is married and has given birth to three children, all of whom attend school. Rebecca sells porridge in her neighborhood. Almost all Ghanaians enjoy eating porridge for breakfast. It is prepared from milled maize or millet grains and then boiled and eaten with sugar, milk and bread or with "kose." Kose is made from milled beans and it is fried with cooking oil so it is ready to be served with the porridge in about 20 minutes. With a growing customer base, she wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of millet, beans, sugar, and milk to increase production. She would be grateful for any assistance.

loans.use: To buy raw materials such as maize, millet, sugar, milk etc.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is 38 years old she is married with four children. All her children are in school through hard work and commitment. His wife is a trader in the community where he lives. He enjoys selling and he is motivated to work hard because he dreams of a better future for his kids. He owns and operates grocery shop and sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk etc. However, he is constrained by low capital to make a meaningful progress. He requests for the loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams etc. to make increased profits. He believes with good customer relation, the loan will enable him materialize her dream. He would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams etc.

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en: Emelia is 35 years old woman who is divorced with two children. One of her children is currently in school. She is a very hardworking young woman who is a hight achiever. Emelia bakes bread and supply to her loyal customers. For the past sixteen years, she has been baking bread and other food pastries while taking care of her household. In spite of the challenges she faces she manages to handle the demands of her customers and successfully meet their requests on time. Her only problem now has to do with adequate funds to buy raw materials as prices are shooting up. She is requesting a loan to remain in business. With the loan she believes she can provide for her family and most especially her children’s educations and her business’ growth.

loans.use: To buy baking materials like bags of flour, sugar, margarine, yeast and firewood etc.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is 50 years old and is a single mother of five children. Three of her children are in school. She is a very hard working woman and works hard to support her children. She trades in Ghana, make slippers, shoes, and sandals for both male and females. She takes delivery of stock from Kumasi in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She purchases them in different sizes, colors, and designs so that her customers can have some variety.  Her loan asks for your assistance to buy stock in bulk. She thanks you in advance.

loans.use: To buy stock in bulk for clothing store

loans.name: Dora

texts.en: Dora is 44 years old. She is married and mother with three children. Currently two are in the basic and junior high school in the community where they live. She is a dealer and supplier of phone cards, recharge units and phone chips. Dora is hard working and very resourced to the upbringing of the family. She says the sale of phone credits has become very lucrative business in Ghana because almost every Ghanaian desires to possess a mobile phone and would definitely buy credit to recharge their phone hand set. She buys her supplies from agents at wholesale prices and gives to her customers at retail prices. She requests for the loan to enable her procure increased stock of Mobile phone credits. She hopes the loan would enable her to increase savings to expand her shop. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To procure increased stock of mobile phones credits and unit transfer and accessories.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is 40 years old. She is married and the mother of three children, all of whom are in school. She works very hard to help her husband take care of their children. She prepares and bakes bread for a living. She started her business four years ago. She overcomes her business challenges with determination and commitment. 

Her bread business brings hope to her family and support from her husband. She has customers who come to her to buy in bulk. Her only problem now is that she doesn't have the money to buy enough raw materials to meet her customer's demand. She is requesting a loan to help her to remain in business and also to save some money for her children's education.

loans.use: To buy baking supplies, including flour, sugar, margarine, yeast and firewood.

loans.name: Afisheitu

texts.en: Afisheitu is 40years old she is married and mother of five children. All her five children are in school in the community where they live. She is resourceful mother who works very hard to provide food and support for her business.  She is a petty trader and sells in the local area market. She enjoys selling, a business through which she makes a living. She sells items like cooking oil, pepper, spices, gari cereal etc. on top of a table in the market. She sometimes hawks with the goods when business is slowed in the market. She takes stock of goods from the nearby villages. She is requesting for the loan to upgrade her inventory. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, spices, pepper, cooking oil etc.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is a 33 year old woman and is a married mother of three children. All of her children are in school and she lives with husband and children. She is a food vendor and serves food like rice with stew. Her demand for food is on high, but she does not have adequate funds for expansion. She has been in food production for four years now and is taking care of the family. She wants to use the loan to buy meat and bags of rice to increase her efficiency and production. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to support the educational needs of her children. With hard work she believes she can repay the loan on time.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat, firewood etc.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is forty – eight years old. She is married and has given birth to five children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town. Comfort is a trader. She trades in ready – made wears such as ladies’ dressed. She buys her goods from Kumasi. Comfort hawks to sell in her community and also treks to nearby communities to sell. She has been in business for over eighteen years. She wants a loan to buy goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy ready-made wears

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is thirty – six years old. She is married and has given birth to two children. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town. Joyce is a trader. She trades in printed textile materials. She buys the textile materials from Kumasi. Joyce hawks to sell in her community and also treks to nearby communities to sell. She has been in business for over twelve years and wants a loan to buy materials in bulk.

loans.use: To buy printed textiles

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is forty-four years old. She is married and has given birth to two children who now attend school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Dormaa, a a commercial and farming town in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. 

Mary works as a seamstress. She designs and sews dresses for her clients. She also has apprentices whom she is training. She set up her workshop by the side of a road in her community. Mary has been in business for over eighteen years and wants a loan to buy fabrics and other sewing accessories in bulk.

loans.use: To buy fabric and sewing accessories

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: Augustina is thirty – nine years old. She is divorced and has given birth to one child. She lives with her son in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town. Augustina is a baker. She bakes bread and supplies to other retailers and beverage sellers in her community. She buys bags of flour and other ingredients from Kumasi. Augustina hawks to sell in her community to sell. She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua is forty – nine years old. She is divorced and has given birth to three children who are all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town. Akosua is a trader. She trades in plantain. She buys from nearby towns and supplies to food vendors and retailers in her community. She also treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. Akosua has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy plantain

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is fifty years old. She is divorced and has given birth to three children who are all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town. She is a trader. Mary trades in tubers of yam. She buys from nearby towns and supplies to food vendors and retailers in her community. She also treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. Mary has been in business for over ten years and wants a loan to buy tubers of yam on large scale.

loans.use: To buy yam

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is forty – two years old. She is married and has give birth to three children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town. Monica is a trader. She trades in maize. She buys bags of maize from nearby towns. She supplies to food vendors and retailers in her community. Monica has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en:
Ramona A. is 34 years old, is seperated with 4 children all under 16 years, and almost all of them are studying in primary school. 
Ramona started her business in 2006- when she returned from Spain, a country where there is better business, she took money to invest in merchandise (new and used clothes)- she has many local people that buy her clothes. 
She invested her loan in buying more merchandise (different types of clothes for spring and summer).

loans.use: Clothing

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en:
Ricardo O. is 57 years old and has been married for thirty-five years to Guillerma Lopez, who is 54 years old. They have six children, three of whom live in the house - the others have their own homes. The ones who are 32, 19, and 15 live with them. Their child who is 32 was paralyzed eleven years ago when he was playing soccer.

For 35 years, Ricardo was an employee of a private business, and at the same time he had a carpentry businesses for six months. He decided to start his own business with a little of his savings from his pervious work.

He wants to use the loan to buy wood and nails. He has various orders for furniture for the end of the year.

loans.use: To buy wood and nails

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en: Rosa is the head of a clothing store and has started saving to start another business to sell merchandise and help her family. She is 26 years old and married to Jorge Mendoza, who is 29 years old. They have two children who are 4 years old and 8 years old. Rosa's dream is to expand her business to have a great clothing store where her clients can find all they want. She wants a loan so she can buy the necessary merchandise. She will use the loan to buy shirts, pants, shoes, blouses, sandals, shoe horns and undergarments for men and women.

loans.use: To buy merchandise and clothing

loans.name: San Cayetano (Comitte De Mujeres) Group

texts.en:
This committee formed in the Neighborhood Toro Blanco of the city of Caaguazú. Sebastiana A. knew the Program through her sister-in-law, who is the president of another comittee, and she was very interested to participate in a Comittee of Women program, where 20 women could work that wanted to secure a profession. With much enthusiasm they formed a group where women could responsibily work together. They are independent with their jobs, where they sell clothes, shoes, food, groceries, and they receive credit. Some received 800,000 gs, other took loans for 600,000 gs, 5000,000 gs, and 300,000 gs, and they invested in buying sugar, beef, wheat, eggs, cheese, shirts, and they want to progress with their loans with Fundación Paraguaya. 
Sebastiana A. wants to use her loan for a small grocery store. 
Grismilda B. S. wants to use her loan for a small grocery store. 
María I. S. wants to use her loan to sell new clothes. 
María R. A. wants to use her loan to sell fruits and vegetables. 
Lucia E. wants to use her loan to sell chickens. 
Elvira B. A. wants to use her loan to sell new clothes. 
Balbina A. wants to use her loan to sell food. 
Gregoria M. M. wants to use his loan to sell fruit. 
A. M. wants to use her loan to sell animal kidneys and liver. 
I. L. wants to use her loan to sell new clothes. 
Aquilina V. wants to use her loan to sell new clothes and undergarments. 
Mabel A. wants to use her loan to sell food. 
Eulalia G. wants to use her loan to sell fruits and vegetables. 
Ildenfonza V. wants to use her loan for a small grocery store. 
Lucia R. M. wants to use her loan to sell food. 
Felicia P. wants to use her loan to sell fruits and vegetables. 
Ceferina C. wants to use her loan to be a dressmaker. 
Delia C. E. wants to use her loan for a small grocery store. 
Delos S. A. A. wants to use her loan for her bartending business. 
Claudia E. wants to use her loan for a small grocery store.

loans.use: Produce, etc.

loans.name: Mirenda

texts.es:
Mirenda es una joven que inicio un negocio de Abarrotes desde hace un año el cual es llamado “Miscelánea Loal”. 
Su padre y su mamá le ayudan con el negocio, este lo puso pensando en ellos ya que son grandes de edad y no pueden conseguir trabajo en otra parte  es por ello que Mirenda preocupada en el bienestar de ellos y agradecida de que fue criada de buena familia quiere darles una mejor calidad de vida una distracción para que no se sientan inútiles por que ellos toda su vida trabajaron para darle una mejor educación a Mirenda. En el negocio ella vende botanas, refrescos, enlatados, jabón de baño, jabón para lavar ropa etc. 
Tiene gran variedad de artículos, pero en este momento ella quiere invertir mas al negocio para cada día vaya progresando y así tener más ganancias y apoyar en la economía de sus padres.
texts.en:
Mirenda is a young woman who started a grocery business a year ago. Her store is called “Miscelánea Loal”.

Her father and mother help with the business. Mirenda kept her parents in mind because they are older and not able to find work elsewhere. She is concerned for their welfare and thankful that she was raised in a good family that strived for a better quality of life. Her parents worked all their lives to provide Mirenda with a good education so that she would not feel useless.

In her business, Mirenda sells snacks, soft drinks, canned goods, bath soaps, laundry detergents, etc. She has a large variety of items, but she wants to invest more into her business so that she can continue to have success each day. She hopes to generate more revenue so that she can support her parents’ financial situation.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Darling Aracely

texts.en: Darling Aracely R. M. is a single mother. Her son is six years old and has not yet started school. Darling is well prepared to run a business. In addition to completing her studies with a degree in business administration, Darling learned from her mom at an early age, about how to run a small business. Darling dreams of having her own store with a large inventory, and ultimately of being a successful business woman with a successful business. This loan will go towards the purchase of cosmetics and clothes for her store. Darling says that the only obstacles in her business are those that one faces daily, and she is extremely grateful to the people who help to support her business through these loans.

loans.use: Capital to buy inventory

loans.name: Los Lirio Group

texts.en:
Rosa is the coordinator of her group 'Los Lirio'. Her story is representative of both her group members and Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated from Haiti to the DR). Rosa's group is based in Los Alcarrizzos, a dusty industrial town north of Santo Domingo where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable at best. Here, Rosa makes her home with her three school-aged children and husband in a simple structure made of cement walls and a tin roof.

Rosa has proved herself to be an excellent associate of Esperanza and has already successfully repaid two loans, which she says have greatly helped her in growing her 'Colmado' (small general store). With this third loan she plans to purchase more goods in bulk to sell to her customers. She purchases sacks of rice, beans, and sugar as well as cans of salsa, all items for which there is constant demand. With the increased profits from a larger business, she plans to buy some extra clothing for her family and continue to support her children more generally as they progress through school. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: rice, cans of salsa, beans, and sugar

loans.name: 15 De Agosto Group
